title: AB 1673
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define a "firearm" as a device designed for use as a weapon that expels a projectile through a barrel by the force of an explosion or combustion. The definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. The Penal Code includes various sections that define the term "firearm" and its exceptions. The definition encompasses devices designed to expel projectiles through explosion or combustion, including rockets and launchers. Certain provisions exclude unloaded antique firearms from the definition. The Penal Code defines "firearm" in various sections, excluding unloaded antique firearms in certain provisions. It also clarifies that in specific sections, a firearm does not include a destructive device or unfinished frame or receiver that can be converted to a finished state. In Sections 17280 and 24680, "firearm" is defined as in Section 922 of Title 18 of the United States Code. In Sections 29010 to 29150, "firearm" includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted to a finished state. The term "frame" and "receiver" refer to the part of a firearm that houses the hammer, bolt, or firing mechanism. Section 16520 of the Penal Code defines a "firearm" as a device designed to expel a projectile through a barrel by combustion. Section 16520 of the Penal Code defines a "firearm" as a device designed to expel a projectile through a barrel by combustion. It includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. The Penal Code defines a "firearm" and includes specific sections that expand on this definition, such as rocket launchers and antique firearms. The Penal Code provides specific sections that further define a "firearm," excluding unloaded antique firearms and destructive devices in certain provisions. It also clarifies the meaning of "firearm" in relation to unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted into a functional condition. In Sections 17280 and 24680, "firearm" is defined as in Section 922 of Title 18 of the United States Code. In Sections 29010 to 29150, "firearm" includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be converted to a functional condition. "Frame" and "receiver" refer to parts of a firearm housing essential components. Section 16520 of the Penal Code defines a "firearm" as a device designed to expel a projectile through a barrel by combustion, including the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections. The Penal Code includes various sections that define and classify firearms, including provisions on rocket launchers and antique firearms. The Penal Code contains sections that define firearms and exclude certain types like unloaded antique firearms, destructive devices, and unfinished frames or receivers that can be converted into functional firearms. In the Penal Code, "firearm" is defined as a device designed for shooting projectiles through a barrel using combustion. It includes the frame or receiver of the weapon, as well as unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted into functional firearms. In the Penal Code, the definition of a "firearm" includes devices designed for shooting projectiles through combustion. It also encompasses the frame or receiver of the weapon, as well as various sections within the code. The Penal Code defines a "firearm" to include rockets and similar explosive devices. It also excludes unloaded antique firearms in certain provisions. The Penal Code excludes unloaded antique firearms in specific provisions related to firearms. It also clarifies the definition of a firearm in various sections, including provisions regarding destructive devices and unfinished frames or receivers. In the Penal Code, the definition of a firearm is clarified to include unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted into functional weapons. This definition aligns with Section 922 of Title 18 of the United States Code. Section 2 of the bill outlines the conditions under which certain sections will become operative, depending on the enactment of other related bills and their effective dates. Section 1.3 of the bill incorporates amendments to the Penal Code proposed by multiple bills, which will only become operative under specific conditions. No reimbursement is required by this act as it pertains to creating new crimes or infractions, changing penalties, or definitions of crimes.
